--- Cedric Beust <cbeust@...> wrote:
> Funny you should say that, because that's exactly
> how TestNG supports
> dependent tests.
> 
> You can specify that a group B of test methods
> "depends on" a group A of
> test methods.  In this case, TestNG guarantees that
> 
> - All methods in group A will be run before any
> method in group B is
> invoked.
> - All methods in group A will have succeeded.  If at
> least one of them
> failed, then all test methods in group B will be
> marked as "SKIPPED" (not
> run), which makes it much easier for you to figure
> out which test exactly
> broke the chain ("cascade effect").

I meant something else. Its in J.B. Rainsberger's book
on page 185: Ignore a test.

Or on this page:
http://www.artima.com/weblogs/viewpost.jsp?thread=4603

Ignored tests are always skipped, but not because
another test failed but because the programmer set the
test to be ignored, which is a kind of "sleep" mode.

Now to your test dependancies. I'll tell you how our
tests are grouped in the suites.

There is a JUnit test suite for every Eclipse project.
Then we have a suite for each component in the
projects. The components can have these groups of
tests: persistance tests (whether entites are
persisted and retrieved correctly according to meta
data, including validation rule testing for these
entities and entity factories), batch program tests
(which either can be legacy data migration batch tests
or fast lane reader batch tests), business logic tests
(like ABC analysis, sales forecast, purchase proposals
and so on), tests for utility classes and some other
groups of tests (but we have no automated GUI tests).

If persistance tests fail, then it would be no use to
run all other tests. If tests for utility classes
fail, then in many cases it is no use to run all other
tests. If batch tests fail, it doesn't mean that
business logic tests will fail and vice versa. This is
a corse grained dependency of our tests. The fine
grained test dependencies are much more of course.

In our team we all know that if persistance tests
fail, we don't have to care about the business logic
test results.

We really have a large project. If the tests reflect
the code structure too close, then refactoring becomes
very time consuming because it affects tests very
much. Thats for example why it is recommended to only
test public methods. My theoretical objection to
maintain dependency information in the tests is that
it is additional work to do and to maintain. If the
dependency changes for the worse, the test dependency
information (annotation) need to be changed. Besides
this, if test group B is no longer dependent of test
group A, then the tests pass although there is no
dependency anymore. It is pure luck for a programmer
to detect that test B is no longer dependent of test
A. Only if a new dependency is created, the tests will
fail. But if a dependency vanishes, the tests will not
fail and will contain misleading dependency
annotations. Isolated tests are more stable to change
than dependent tests I think.

Don't get me wrong. I argued here against JUnit in
favor of Design by Contract a few years ago. Now I
like JUnit, which can apply to TestNG too, or not, who knows.
